content.description: Shares the start with Loading Zone in a left facing dihedral. Straight up and through a crux bulge mantling onto a platform to the right. Harder than it looks from the ground. It is possible to top rope this from the chains on top of Loading Zone. (Use the directional bolt and some webbing)
content.protection: Standard rack to 4"; hexes(!) work well. As an alternative, one can climb/protect the thin crack just to the left of the dihedral.
content.location: The largest left facing dihedral in the center/right of the wall.

content.description: Easy hands to a deceptive bulge/roof. Crux is dealing with the flaring fists above! Great fun, protection can be difficult above the bulge.
content.protection: Standard rack to 4".
content.location: Just to the right of Scatmando, the largest roof at the crag. Difficult to build toprope/belay without long webbing to extend over edges.

content.description: Start in the steep corner to the left of 'The Finger Crack', pull through a fun roof bulge with good hands. Turns into a low angle O.W., which can either be fun and easy or scary and hard.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3". An optional 5" protects the offwidth adequately.
content.location: Start to the left of thin crack on the nose in the dark, sometimes damp corner.

climbs.name: The Three Idiots Traverse
climbs.fa: Jadian, Jesse Patton, Mike Vinci Germar

content.description:
SO there they were, end of the day, enjoying a beer and/or cider, talking about the things we talk about after some good redpoints, and SOMEONE came up with the idiotic idea of doing a traverse of the whole wall.  And off they went.

The crux is at the very end, passing under "Loading Zone", a no feet thin hand crack.  The whole is quite entertaining, with a lot of thought needed to protect it well while reducing rope drag. Stay high enough to avoid groundfall potential.

P1) 5.8 Go as far as you can until the rope drag keeps you from moving. Lower off.

P2) 5.10- The follower is as exposed as the leader: It's a traverse!
content.protection: Double rack, .3-3". Nuts. Many many shoulder length and double length slings. Draws. There is a wide range of protection in most areas. This thing eats up gear, necessary to protect ground fall and the follower.
content.location: Starting at the far left of the wall, climb up ~15', and begin moving right. The route stays under the lower roofs across the wall. When the rope drag becomes unbearable, lower off, and bring the follower along. Ends after passing under the roof below the route "Loading Zone" before the rock becomes a jumble of weeds and moss. The follower must downclimb the end, moving protection down with him/her.

content.description: A fun face climb when your crack hands just won't take any more punishment. Climb without using the cracks to either side. May feel thin for the grade.
content.protection: Toprope. Requires gear to set.
content.location: The bulgy face just left of Cafe Society. Starts under the mini roofs.

content.description: One of the best lines at the crag, 5.9 for those with ample hands width, harder for those with smaller hands. Wide hands, to fat fists, a vertical heaven which ends too soon. Crux is just having the time to get in gear. Really fun.
content.protection: Doubles 1-3" 1- 4" optional. Can make nuts work in spots, but it is short enough not to need them.
content.location: To the far right of the crag, the dead vertical fat crack. Can be muddy/damp at the start in springtime.

content.description: Has to be one of the best at the crag. Easier than it looks, maybe. The more you climb the crack (leaving the face holds out) the harder it becomes. Good practice for pulling difficult roofs. Climb up the well protected corner to a fun hand traverse left. Pull onto the ledge...or head straight up the crack.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3". There are anchors for the next line to the left which can be used with a little creativity, long slings and a directional.
content.location: The largest roof at the crag.

content.description: Start up the thin crack on the face of the 'Loading Zone' Buttress. Pull the bulge, thin face to the finish of Loading Zone. Optional (easier) to break right and finish on 'Blow By'. Difficult to give this a grade, as there are many variations/exits.
content.protection: At this point this is a toprope project. Keeping in tune with the wishes of the developers of the area, the route has not been bolted from toprope.
content.location: The nose of the 'Loading Zone Buttress'. Easily toproped from the Loading Zone belay.

content.description: Starts in the same alcove as Cafe Society, breaking up and right. Has cleaned up nicely since the FA.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3".
content.location: About 10' right of the year round spring at the base. Ascends the obvious weakness to the left of the roof bulge of Lady Fantasy.

content.description: The line which is the namesake of the crag. Start up Yesterday's Man, at the obvious crack leading of to the right exit around the bulge (crux for some) and head up through 2 VERY OLD and needing to be replaced bolts. This lead is for solid 11+/12 climbers!
content.protection: Gear to 4" (see Yesterday's Man), draws for bolts. If toproping be careful of rope direction and sawing across the face during traverse.
content.location: Start up Yesterday's Man, at the crux of which you move right out obvious crack. It is possible to protect the traverse, watch for rope drag.

content.description: A classic roof/bulge crack. Great line to practice on toprope. Crux for most is pulling into the pod at the bulge. It's all about the feet!
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", double 1&2. Slings.
content.location: One of the prominent features at the Zone, easily recognized. A bulge split by a handcrack which says "climb me, if you can".

content.description: An entertaining line up a thin face to a fun (10.c) roof. First bolt is quite high (20'+) but can be clipped by using the easy 5th on the left and/or stick clip. Needs a few ascents to clean it up, as with most routes here. Originally led on gear (bouble rp's, thin rack to 2", slings. 10.c R/X). For those with fat fingers, the roof can be a struggle.
content.protection: 8 bolts, chains on top. Optional 1" piece for the roof.
content.location: To the left of the namesake route, the Loading Zone; the only bolted face. Look up to see the obvious roof at the finish, with chains hanging over the edge above.

content.description: Layback a wide crack for a few bolts, then finish with a couple of techy face moves to the anchor.
content.protection: 4 bolts, 2-bolt anchor.  Walk around to clean anchors, no chains.
content.location: Furthest right route, look for the bolted offwidth.

content.description: This is a heady lead. Original FA's call it PG13...more R than not. Thin face moves protected by just enough (maybe) gear and 1 older bolt, up and over a small roof bulge 20' off the ground. A fun line to toprope, too.
content.protection: Thin, small gear <1". Takes nuts well. Ballnuts come in very handy.
content.location: Just left of large roof. This line sees little traffic, sometimes hard to see where to go.

content.description: Climb the first 15' of 'Sure Thing', then look left to find the bolt, just out of reach. Step out onto the face, good hands, crazy feet, clip bolt, move up and search for the well hidden holds. As of April 2016, the bolt, a rusty button spinner, is NOT to be trusted.
content.protection: 1 bolt, rack to 2", doubles .3-.5. Difficult to build anchor on large ledge just below top-out.
content.location: When the sun is shining, the bolt is easy to see. The penultimate left most line, on the improbable face. Walk off either left or right. Infrequently climbed, can be very dirty/mossy.

content.description: A thin finger crack starts at the base of the jutting rock and arches up and to the right. Harder for those with large fingers.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", emphasis on small cams and nuts.
content.location: The nose of the jutting rock to the left of Scantmando. One of the thinnest cracks at the crag.

content.description: The furthest right line at the crag, a thin corner leads to a bulge 15 off the ground. More difficult than it looks and very fun.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3".
content.location: Just to the right of The fist crack Serenity Now, the farthest left route.

content.description: This will be a better climb as it gets climbed and cleaned. A difficult to see left facing corner, mossy, dirty, sometimes bushy. SOunds fun, right?
content.protection: Standard rack to 3"
content.location: The farthest left line at the crag, a bit of a scramble to get to or see.

content.description:
Start on "Io's Hidden Pleasure Point", after the fifth bolt head left to the overhanging roof, clip 2 bolts, pull the tough roof/mantle, finish at the chains for "Io's...".

The original meaning of deviant is "turning out of the way". Well protected, can be damp in spring.
content.protection: 7 draws, lockers for the chains. Easily top roped.
content.location: The only sport route at LZ, look for the shiny bolts. Rap, or walk off to climbers left. Stick clip is nice.

content.description: Right facing broken dihedral. Climb the crack, use the face, many options. Ends up and left. Can be combined w/ 'Io's Hidden Pleasure Points' by traversing right under the roof and exiting up the overhung hand crack (10.c).
content.protection: Single rack to 1". Double 2"&3". Nuts
content.location: To the left of 'Io's Hidden Pleasure Points', starts on easy 5th class blocks.

content.description:
Technical and sustained climbing on a blunted arete.  The crux probably comes pulling past the second bolt, but the route is stacked with 5.11 moves.  Full-on for its relatively short length.

Blowing the second clip could be real bad...clipping off the left-hand undercling/sidepull is recommended.  Or stick clip both 1st and 2nd bolts.
content.protection: 4 bolts, anchors.  No chains, walk around to clean.
content.location: Far right side of the cliff, look for a bolted arete to the left of a hand/fist crack.

content.description: Perhaps the most popular climb at the crag, a great way to get on the rock and shake the cobwebs from your trad rack. Fun.
content.protection: Gear to 3", a couple of shoulder length slings, nuts.
content.location: 10' right of year round spring, starts in the alcove just left of Lady Fantasy.

content.description: A left facing (almost) dihedral/corner. Climb the solid hand crack to the off-fist bulge, the crux. Finding gear is the fun part on this one, and it is not over till you hit the top.
content.protection: Gear to 4". Double 2&3.
content.location: Right hand crack to the right of the largest roof at the crag (Scatmando)

content.description: To the right of The Loading Zone, the corner of the bulge. Start up the hand crack, move left onto the face past 2 older, questionable bolts.
content.protection: Gear to 3", easy to suss out from the base. Toprope needs to be extended over the edge.
content.location: The right hand side of the Loading Zone bulge. Walk off to climber right.

content.description: Head up through 3 bolts of 5.10-, staying to the right of the bolts. Cross the bolt line and pull the bulge on a looong deadpoint to a jug. Make a balancy mantel, then finish up the last 2 bolts of "Blow By".
content.protection: 7 bolts, chain anchors.
content.location: Second to the right of the bolted routes, on the right side of the crag.

content.description: Start in the alcove to the left of the big roof (Scatmando) going up the left hand crack straight up. Meets 'Finger Crack' at the false top.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", double 2&3".
content.location: In the alcove to the left of Scantmando.

content.description: Start in the alcove to the left of the big roof (Scatmando) going up the right hand corner crack. Jam and stem up to a roof bulge (crux) which gets a little wide.
content.protection: Rack to 4", double 2-4", slings.
content.location: To the left of Scatmando. Not climbed often, may need a little brushing in spots.

content.description: Either start on the easy 5th class blocks at the start of corner shot or straight up the crack to the left. Hands to off-fists. Wander through variations tending straight up to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack, doubles 2&3". Some people use a 4"
content.location: Under the prominent roof on the bulge (Lady Fantasy). Route goes onto the dihedral face to the right of the roof. Thin hands to off-fist.
